Often in mathematics, it is useful to be able to compute an approximation to a given function . One way of doing this is to find some for which is easy to compute. We can then calculate the approximate value of when is near . We will call this approximation . More concretely, we might say is near when for some threshold value of our choosing. One way of settling upon such an might be by determining an acceptable upper bound on the error of our approximation and then finding the greatest such that: \[\left|f(x) - f_{a}(x)\right| < U \quad \forall x \in (a - \varepsilon,\ a + \varepsilon)\] The simplest such approximation is called the tangent line approximation and is given by: \[f_{a}(x) = f(a) + f’(a)(x - a)\] Let’s try to understand intuitively what this approximation is computing. We start by calculating , so you can visualize the initial approximation as a point resting on the graph of at the point . This approximation is acceptable only for values of that lie exceedingly close to . To improve the approximation, we then calculate . Note that if then . Conversely, if then . The sign of tells us the direction we will be moving along the tangent line to at the point . If is negative we will move to the left of , and if is positive we will move to the right. Now we calculate the value of . Recall that is the slope of the tangent line to the graph of at the point . Remember too that a slope is defined as . Therefore, when we multiply conceptually we are multiplying our \textit{run} () by (). The runs will cancel out in the multiplication leaving us with a rise, i.e. . We add to this expression to obtain our final approximation .

Example: Let , and suppose we want to approximate near . To compute our approximation, we will need to know so let’s calculate that. \[f’(x) = 4x^3 + 12x^2 + 4x - 1\] Now we can compute our approximation. We have: \begin{align} \begin{split} f_{1}(x) & = f(1) + f’(1)(x - 1)
& = 7 + 19(x - 1)
& = 19x - 12 \end{split} \end{align} Notice that this is exactly the equation of the tangent line to at .
now, we need to find the interval such that for we have: \[\left|f(x) - f_{1}(x)\right| = 0.1\] So we solve for as follows: \begin{align} \begin{split} x^4 + 4x^3 + 2x^2 - x + 1 - 19x + 12 &= 0.1
x^4 + 4x^3 + 2x^2 - 20x + 12.9 &= 0 \end{split} \end{align} This quartic would be quite difficult to solve by hand, so we utilize the help of a computational mathematics software package such as Matlab to calculate the zeros. We find that or . Now, keep in mind that these -values that we found represent the endpoints of our interval . Since , we find that or . We want to equal the minimum of these two values in order to ensure that we stay within our error bound to both the left and right of . Therefore, we have and the interval in which our approximation falls within of the actual value of is .

There are a few observations we should make regarding this example. First, note how small the interval is in which our approximation is accurate to within of . Why is this? Well, there are a few reasons. First off, the tangent line approximation is not, in general, a very accurate approximation of the global behavior of . This is because the tangent line approximates based on the value of the slope at the point , and for most functions the actual graph of stays close to the tangent line at for only a very short time before curving away. Of course, this is not true universally, for if is of the form then, in fact, we have: \[f_{a}(x) = f(x) \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{R}\]

The foregoing analysis of our approximation begs the following question: How can we quantify the rate at which curves away from it’s tangent line approximation at any given point? The answer is that we can use to calculate the rate at which our function deviates from it’s tangent line approximation. For more general curves, the concept of curvature from differential geometry is used. More on this later.

Now that we know we can approximate a function using it’s derivative, we might begin to wonder whether it would be possible to increase the accuracy of such an approximation by incorporating the use of higher degree derivatives of . Indeed, one might postulate that for a function having derivatives a function exists for which . Indeed, for any function , such a function exists called the -th degree Taylor Polynomial.

The -th degree Taylor Polynomial centered at , designated , is given by:

\[P_{n}(x) = \sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{f^{(i)}(x)}{i!}(x-a)^i\] Note first that in the case where the Taylor polynomial reduces to the tangent line approximation . As previously mentioned, one of the problems with this approximation is that it does a rather poor job of representing our function’s curvature on anything but a small interval. One might then reason that a quadratic function might better approximate the value of for a wider range of values. This is indeed the case, and such an approximating quadratic is given by . Similarly, the cubic approximation given by provides an incremental improvement over the quadratic, the quartic, , gives greater accuracy than the cubic, and so on and so forth. Let’s try to approximate the function given in our tangent approximation example using a Taylor polynomial.
